conversation.text: Let's make panko bread crumbs. Start by getting out a rimmed baking sheet and preheating your oven to 250
evidence: Preheat the oven to 250 °F (121 °C) and get out a rimmed baking sheet.

conversation.text: Do I need to use a rimmed baking sheet?
Yes, you don't want the breadcrumbs to slide off.
evidence: It's important to use a rimmed sheet

conversation.text: Okay, the sheet is out and oven is on, what next?
Cut a loaf of bread into strips.
evidence: Cut a crustless loaf of bread into 3 to 4 strips.

conversation.text: Can I use the crust?
No, but you can cut off the crust of the bread you have.
evidence: Cut a crustless loaf of bread

conversation.text: How many strips do I need to cut the bread into?
Three or four strips.
Do I cut the bread into slices first or do I want 3 or 4 long strips of bread?
Yes you want to slice them first.
Okay, the bread is sliced and cut into strips, what next?
Do you have a food processor, blender, or grater?
evidence: If you don't have a food processor,

conversation.text: I have a blender.
Next you want to make the bread strips into flakey crumbs.
How do I do that with a blender?
Put the bread slices in the blender and pulse it.
evidence: pulse it 1 to 2 times in a blender.

conversation.text: How many times do I pulse it?
One or two times.
Okay I pulsed it one time.
What size are your bread crumbs?
They are really big.
Pulse it again so the crumbs are big instead of really big.
Okay, the flakes are big, what next?
You want to put your bread crumbs on your rimmed baking sheet.
evidence: Spread the breadcrumbs on the rimmed baking sheet

conversation.text: Okay it's all spread out.
How thick is the layer the crumbs in your rimmed pan?
evidence: will be more than ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) t

conversation.text: It's about an inch thick.
That's too thick, get out another rimmed pan and split the crumbs evenly between the two pans.
Okay, done. Why did it need to be split?
If the layer is too thick the bread crumbs won't bake evenly and become crispy enough.
evidence: ensure that the panko becomes crispy as it bakes.

conversation.text: Oh okay, that makes sense. Are they ready to go in the oven?
Is your oven finished preheating?
Yes! I'm ready to go.
Put the breadcrumbs in the oven and mix them every 5 minutes for 20 to 30 minutes.
Why do I need to mix them?
You don't want your breadcrumbs to get too brown.
Okay,  what next?
How long have they been baking? How do the breadcrumbs look?
evidence: should become crunchy, but remain pale in color.

conversation.text: They've been in for 20 minutes and they're kind of soft still pale.
Keep it in the oven for 10 more minutes. You want the panko to be crunchy.
Okay, it's been 10 minutes and they're crunchy but still pale. Can I use them in a recipe now?
You can take them out of the oven but you need to cool them before you can use them.
evidence: Let the panko cool completely before you use it or store it

conversation.text: Can I store them right away then?

recipe.title: How to Make Panko Bread Crumbs

procedure.summary: Preheat the oven to 250 °F (121 °C) and get out a rimmed baking sheet.
procedure.description: Set 1 to 2 rimmed baking sheets on your work surface. It's important to use a rimmed sheet so the breadcrumbs won't slide off of the sheet when you put them in and take them out of the oven.

procedure.summary: Cut a crustless loaf of bread into 3 to 4 strips.
procedure.description: If you don't have crustless bread, use a sharp serrated knife to trim off and discard the crusts. Place your crustless bread on a cutting board, cut it into slices, and cut each slice into 3 to 4 strips. You can cut them lengthwise or horizontally. While white panko is traditionally made with crustless bread, you can leave the crust on to create tan panko.

procedure.summary: Shred the bread in a food processor to make large flakes.
procedure.description: Put the shredding disc on your food processor and turn the machine on. Slowly put the strips of crustless bread into the machine. This should make big flakes of breadcrumbs. If you don't have a food processor, grate the bread against the coarse side of a box grater or pulse it 1 to 2 times in a blender.

procedure.summary: Spread the breadcrumbs on the rimmed baking sheet.
procedure.description: If it looks as though the breadcrumbs will be more than ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick on 1 sheet, divide them between 2 sheets. Keeping the breadcrumbs in an even layer will ensure that the panko becomes crispy as it bakes.

procedure.summary: Bake the panko breadcrumbs for 20 to 30 minutes.
procedure.description: Put the rimmed baking sheet in the preheated oven and cook it until the panko becomes crispy. Use a spoon or spatula to stir the breadcrumbs every 5 minutes as they bake. Stirring the panko frequently will prevent it from browning. The panko should become crunchy, but remain pale in color.

Remove the rimmed baking sheet from the oven and set it on a wire rack. Let the panko cool completely before you use it or store it. If you store the panko before it's finished cooling, the moisture in the breadcrumbs will cause them to spoil faster. It will probably take at least 1 hour for the breadcrumbs to cool. They'll continue to dry as they cool.
